transcript.text: hello I'm Shalom Shalom it is the fifth
night of Hanukkah tonight as the Shabbat
has ended on December the 20th 2014 the
fifth day of Hanukkah has begun as the
Sun set tonight and Sun this fifth day
of Hanukkah I just want to talk briefly
about the true meaning of Hanukkah and
why why Hanukkah is so important you
know we all probably know the history
behind it if you don't you should read
the first and second book of Maccabees
which are historical books that detail
quite accurately the events surrounding
the very first Hanukkah but in a
nutshell Hanukkah was the time in which
the small band of rebels known as The
Maccabees had driven back the mightiest
Empire in the world the Greek Empire at
the time and they liberated Israel
liberated Jerusalem and liberated the
temple and it took them eight days to
fully cleanse the temple to repair it to
restore it to remove all the idolatry
that the Greek Emperor had put inside
and to fully dedicate it and cleanse it
and just as Hanukkah was a season of
cleansing and purifying and restoring
the temple so to this should be a season
in which we examine our lives and we ask
the Holy Spirit to remove any idols in
our life any idols in our heart in our
temple you know the scripture says that
our body is a temple for the Holy Spirit
and so we should during this time also
see to cleanse out our own temples and
make sure that there's no sin no
idolatry if we've been struggling with
sinful habits or we've allowed iniquity
to to take to take hold in our lives
anyway we should seek to ask the Holy
Spirit to remove those things from us
during this season and to rededicate
ourselves to Yahshua promising to stay
pure to stay holy to walk in his word to
walk in his spirit to cleave to his
Commandments and to listen to his voice
to be pure because that's what the true
meaning of Chanukah is all about it's
not about the dreidels or the block
block T's or the
the storytelling it's about living a
life of purity and holiness about
cleansing about repentance about
restoration and and rededication it is
after all known as the feast of
dedication that's what it's called in
the book of John 10:22 and so we need to
we need to ask yahushua to help us to
live wholly to live pure to get our
lives clean before him on this Chanukah
because that is what Chanukah the feast
of dedication is all about rededicating
our lives to him and just as that temple
was cleansed on the very first Chanukah
long ago we should ask him to cleanse
our temples during this season and I was
sharing today during our we had a
special Chanukah service today for
Shabbat and I was sharing as we were
going over John 10:22 and the following
scriptures where Yahshua actually
celebrates Hanukkah the feast of
dedication I was sharing how you know
what better time to rededicate our lives
to Yahshua to examine our hearts to ask
the spirit to remove all addictions to
sin and all bad habits and all sinful
things what better time to get clean
when the rest of the world is you know
going to parties and getting drunk and
getting wrapped up and giving gifts to
each other and really getting very
worldly this is one of the most worldly
times of the year this Christmas season
so what better way to stand out from the
world and to be set apart than to
observe Hanukkah the feasts of
dedication by dedicating our lives back
to purity of course this is a very
festive time it's known as the second
Sukkot because you know the Maccabees
they were not able to celebrate Sukkot
because they were fighting the Greeks so
they kept a second Sukkot during
Hanukkah which is why it's eight
another reason why it's eight days this
is like a second Sukkot so it's a time
of joy and festivity and partying and
and rejoicing and and and to eat you
know eat well and and everything but
also it's a time to rededicate yourself
to him
and to make sure your temple is fully
cleaned and pure as you go forward from
this time forth so that his blessings
can be upon you this is Daniel John Lee
with tor restoration ministries wishing
everyone a very happy Chanukah on this
fifth day of the eight-day festival of
dedication of Chanukah Shalom
